verses.text: But now, Job, listen to my words; pay attention to everything I say.
verses.comment: Elihu begins his response to Job, seeking to gently correct him. The invitation to listen again foreshadows later New Testament calls to hear truth (Mark 4:9).

verses.text: Look, I will open my mouth; my tongue will speak from my heart.
verses.comment: Elihu stresses sincerity and truthfulness, a theme consistent with the wisdom literature and prophets (Psalm 15:2).

verses.text: My words come from an upright heart; my lips speak what I know to be true.
verses.comment: Elihu claims to speak with integrity and truth—a reminder of prophetic roles in later scripture (Jer. 1:7).

verses.text: The Spirit of God has made me; the breath of the Almighty gives me life.
verses.comment: A strong reference to Genesis 2:7, paralleling how the Spirit gives life. This prefigures spiritual rebirth in Christ by the Spirit (John 3:5-8).

verses.text: Answer me, if you can; prepare your case and stand before me.
verses.comment: A courtroom scene, echoing much of Job’s setting, foreshadows Christ as our advocate and the judgment to come (1 John 2:1).

verses.text: See, I am just like you before God; I also have been formed from clay.
verses.comment: Elihu stresses human equality before God—a foundational theology for both Old and New Covenants (Rom. 3:23–24).

verses.text: So you do not need to be afraid of me; I will not press you too hard.
verses.comment: Elihu offers gentle correction—paralleling the gentle invitation from Christ (Matt. 11:28-30).

verses.text: But you have said in my hearing—I have heard your very words:
verses.comment: Elihu reminds Job of his own statements, demonstrating the importance of accountability—later fulfilled in Christ’s teachings (Matt. 12:36).

verses.text: 'I am pure, without wrongdoing; I am clean, and there is no guilt in me.
verses.comment: Job’s claims of innocence foreshadow the need for a mediator and the insufficiency of self-justification (Rom. 3:10).

verses.text: Yet God finds occasions against me; he counts me as his enemy.
verses.comment: This verse reflects human feelings of abandonment, which are answered by the nearness brought through Christ (Rom. 5:10).

verses.text: He puts my feet in the stocks; he watches all my paths.'
verses.comment: The image of suffering under God’s discipline points to the mystery of suffering and redemptive purpose, later revealed in Christ (Heb. 12:6-7).

verses.text: But I tell you, you are not right in this—God is greater than any person.
verses.comment: Elihu corrects Job’s self-justification, pointing instead to God’s transcendence and wisdom.

verses.text: Why do you complain against him that he does not give an account for all his actions?
verses.comment: This anticipates Paul’s argument about God’s sovereignty (Rom. 9:20). The text upholds the mystery of God’s wisdom.

verses.text: For God does speak—now one way, now another—though people may not perceive it.
verses.comment: Highlights divine revelation, which foreshadows the many ways God will later speak through Jesus and the Spirit (Heb. 1:1-2).

verses.text: In a dream, in a vision of the night, when deep sleep falls upon people as they slumber in bed,
verses.comment: God’s use of dreams is a frequent Old Testament motif, fulfilled in divine guidance in both Old and New Testaments (Matt. 2:13).

verses.text: then he opens the ears of people and gives them instruction to correct them,
verses.comment: Emphasizes discipline through revelation, encouraging receptiveness to God’s correction (Heb. 12:5-11).

verses.text: so that he may turn people from evil deeds and keep them from pride.
verses.comment: God’s correction aims at humility and repentance—a theme later perfected in Christ’s call to conversion (Luke 24:47).

verses.text: He spares their soul from the pit, their life from crossing over into death.
verses.comment: Here is a glimpse of God’s desire to save, foreshadowing Christ’s triumph over death (1 Cor. 15:54).

verses.text: Or someone may be disciplined with pain on their bed and constant distress in their bones,
verses.comment: Physical suffering is seen as a tool for correction—a shadow of suffering’s redemptive purpose fulfilled in Christ (1 Pet. 2:21).

verses.text: so that their appetite detests food, and their soul loathes the choicest meals.
verses.comment: Describes the effects of suffering; it may bring humility and dependence on God.

verses.text: Their flesh wastes away to nothing, and their unseen bones stick out.
verses.comment: Vivid imagery for severe suffering, which later has resonance in the suffering servant passages (Isa. 53:3-5).

verses.text: Their soul draws near the pit, and their life to the messengers of death.
verses.comment: Reference to being close to death. Points toward the necessity of deliverance—fulfilled in the hope of resurrection (John 11:25).

verses.text: Yet if there is an angel on their side, a mediator, one out of a thousand, to declare to a person what is right for them,
verses.comment: Hints strongly at the necessity of a mediator—a role fully revealed in Christ (1 Tim. 2:5). The mention of an angel also alludes to the theme of intercession found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: and he is gracious to them and says, 'Spare them from going down to the pit; I have found a ransom for them,'
verses.comment: The concept of a ransom points ahead to Christ’s sacrificial atonement. Early shadows of redemption and substitution are seen here.

verses.text: then their flesh is renewed like a child’s; they return to the days of their youth.
verses.comment: Renewal after deliverance suggests resurrection and new life—a motif later central to the hope in Christ (2 Cor. 4:16).

verses.text: They pray to God, and he is favorable to them; they see his face with joy and are restored to righteousness.
verses.comment: Restored fellowship and righteousness through prayer—anticipates the New Testament doctrine of reconciliation (2 Cor. 5:18-19).

verses.text: He will sing before others and say, 'I sinned and perverted what was right, but I was not repaid as I deserved.'
verses.comment: Confession and mercy are highlighted. An early example of public profession and the power of grace.

verses.text: He rescued me from going down to the pit, and I will live to enjoy the light.'
verses.comment: Deliverance from death. A prefigurement of resurrection to new life in Christ (John 8:12).

verses.text: God does all these things to a person—twice, even three times—
verses.comment: Repetition of mercy and warning shows God’s persistent pursuit of the sinner. God’s patience and willingness to save are themes throughout Scripture.

verses.text: to bring back their soul from the pit, that they may be enlightened with the light of life.
verses.comment: Restoration to life prefigures the light and life brought through Christ to all who believe (John 1:4–5).

verses.text: Pay attention, Job, listen to me; be silent, and I will speak.
verses.comment: Elihu’s call to listen reflects biblical wisdom teaching. Listening to revealed wisdom is a repeated command in both testaments (Matt. 17:5).

verses.text: If you have anything to say, answer me; speak, for I desire to justify you.
verses.comment: Elihu invites dialogue, showing that true wisdom seeks understanding and reconciliation.

verses.text: If not, then listen to me; be silent, and I will teach you wisdom.
verses.comment: Closes with the importance of receiving wisdom from above—a theme continued in Christ, who is the fullness of wisdom (Col. 2:3).
